geeklist.title: The Australian Year End Math Trade 2011
geeklist.description:
This is the next Aussie math trade and according to Niel T, probably number 7 :D
This Math Trade is brought to you by co-op of Friendless, tiggers and Amiguero.
Once again, the cash option as per the previous two Math Trades is here. So let's start with the boring bit:
By posting an item to this list you are agreeing that you can mail it anywhere in Australia at your expense. If it looks like that's going to cost a lot, make sure you don't trade it for something crap.
There will be [b]NO removal of entries possible[/b] as this made it difficult for some people to track items.
More details about the cash bids look here
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/483458/australian-ultimate-trade-subscription-thread-and
[b][size=18]Specific Rules:[/size][/b]
:star: This trade is open to Australian BGGers only.
:star: This trade is open to board games, expansions, card games, game accessories, and the like. Please don't add anything else. If you intend to allow a game to be exchanged for cash (i.e. you're selling), please include the amount you will accept for it in the price. You may consider compare current market prices (ebay, BGG, local shop)
:star: In ALL cases, [b]SENDER PAYS SHIPPING[/b]. Even if you're selling a game for cash, [b]SENDER PAYS SHIPPING[/b]. Even to Perth or Townsville or Hobart. So, make sure you set your price high enough that you would be happy to pay shipping to anywhere else in Australia out of that money.
:star: Consider the Australian Post option of flat-rate box previously suggested. More details [url=http://auspost.ebay.com.au/flat-rate-box?clk_rvr_id=288654101739]here[/url].
[b]Note[/b]: BGG runs a marketplace where sellers pay 3% commission to BGG, and I believe that this should apply here as well. As Aldie's debt-collectors don't get over this way very much, I suggest that sellers make a donation of that 3% using the standard BGG donation system.
:star: Traders will not be required to add cash items to the geeklist - that will be handled in the want lists. In the case that a buyer offers more than a seller is asking, the buyer will pay the seller's price. Sorry sellers, this is not an auction, this is a maths trade, and you only get as much as you ask for.
[b]Limits:[/b]
Feel free to put as many items on the list as you want. Duplicates of items already on the list are okay. You can combine multiple games into one item (e.g. Carcassonne plus expansions).
Describe the edition, language, and condition of the game. Pick a picture that represents the game you're offering if there are multiple versions. If necessary, take a picture of the game, upload it to your gallery, and use that image.
Count pieces to make sure the games are complete, and accurately list any components that are missing or damaged. Please look at your trade pile to make sure the game is really there.
In order to make your items more (or less) appealing, you may want to add one or more "sweeteners" to the item listing -- an expansion, a related game, or a completely unrelated item that you think will make it a more desirable package.
Items for which there is no BGG listing can be listed as Miscellaneous Game Accessory.
[b]Algorithm:[/b]
Trade lists will be found by TradeMaximizer using SCALED-PRIORITIES, ALLOW-DUMMIES, REQUIRE-COLONS and REQUIRE-USERNAMES switches. The actual code is a heavily modified version of Trade Maximiser 1.3a, modified to allow geeklist integration (as we've been using in Australia for a couple of years) and now the cash bids. The (Java) source code will be available to anyone who's interested.
[b]Deadlines:[/b]
Add items to the list by: [size=10][b][-]6pm[/-] 11pm Sunday 8th of January, 2012[/b][/size]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time
Official item list posted by: [size=10][b]6pm Wednesday 11th of January, 2012[/b][/size]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time
[COLOR=#000099][b]Math trade closed for posting items and comments[/b] [/COLOR]
Want Lists Due By: [size=18][b]6pm Monday 16th of January, 2012[/b][/size]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time
[COLOR=#000099][b]Want list submission via GeekMail to[/b] [/COLOR]
[user=Friendless][/user]
Official Results Posted By: [size=10][b]6pm Wednesday 18th of January, 2012[/b][/size]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time
[COLOR=#003399][size=18]Australian Math Trade No. 9 Official results in the link below:[/size][/COLOR]
http://friendless.servegame.org/stats/result.html
Details about the Most wanted and unwanted [geekurl=/thread/729633/aussie-year-end-math-trade-2011/page/6][size=18][COLOR=#003399]HERE[/COLOR][/size][/geekurl]
There really is no leeway for that, as people may need to get their games to a willing 'games mule' attending CanCon. [b]Note:[/b] There is no direct link between CanCon and this Math Trade, but it is a handy event to exchange items at for those attending.
[b]Format:[/b]
The official item list will be of a format something like: 001-TWIXT 002-BMOON 003-PUERT 004-TICHU
Want lists must be submitted in a format like
([i]your user name[/i]-tiggers) 001-TWIXT : 004-TICHU 002-BMOON
indicating that tiggers, the person who put item 001, a Twixt game, into the list would be willing to accept either item 004, a Tichu game, or item 002, Blue Moon, in trade for it. The order of listing is your order of preference, in case both trades are possible.
The order of wants is a tiebreaker only. The system will first try to maximise the number of trades, even if this means that you get your last preference. The order of your wants will only be considered if there are multiple ways to get the maximum trades. But, fear not! You will never get a game that is not on your want list.
If you put 5 games on this trade list, you will be submitting 5 different want lists.
You may also submit want lists for cash bids. In that case, you write something like this:
([i]your user name[/i]-tiggers) $20 : 004-TICHU 002-BMOON
meaning that tiggers has $20 and he'll pay it for either Tichu or Blue Moon. You could also write this:
([i]your user name[/i]-tiggers) $10 : 004-TICHU ([i]your user name[/i]-tiggers) $20 : 002-BMOON
meaning that tiggers will pay $10 for Tichu and $20 for Blue Moon, so tiggers could be up for $30 total. To ensure that you don't spend all of your beer money, you can add a spending limit just like this:
([i]your user name[/i]-tiggers) LIMIT : $30
which means that no matter what happens, tiggers won't win trades such that he has to spend more than $30. I'll tell you how that works. We run the trade algorithm, and inspect the results. If anyone has exceeded their spending limit, their highest-priced successful bid is removed and the algorithm is re-run. Continue until all spending limits are satisfied. If you don't specify a spending limit, the program infers a limit which is the highest amount you've been for any single item. That will be a rather conservative limit, but follows the maxim of no nasty surprises.
To sell a game, you can submit a trade list like this:
([i]your user name[/i]-tiggers) 001-TWIXT : 004-TICHU 002-BMOON $30
meaning that for Twixt tiggers will accept Tichu, or Blue Moon, or $30 from anyone who's offering cash.
Finally, do not try to screw the system. The program will reject nonsense like this:
(tiggers) $10: $20 (tiggers) %CASH: $20 (tiggers) $10: %CASH (tiggers) $20: $10
and furthermore John reserves the right to change the program to reject anything else he sees as a scam and not an honest trade. Please post any questions in the Geeklist Comments below.
[b]Detailed discussions should be post [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/729633/aussie-year-end-math-trade-2011][COLOR=#0033CC][size=18]HERE[/size][/COLOR][/url].[/b]
[b]UPDATE[/b] Math trade is open for all the Geek domains. Items for RPG and Video Games can be included.

I have noticed that lots of people are indicating whether they are going to Cancon, or at least can forward their games there... However I do not see the point, since "sender pays shipping"!
Will any buyer decide what games to put on their "want" lists (for which they will not pay shipping), based on whether the seller or game will be in Cancon? I certainly think it would be a nice touch to reduce sellers' costs, but I just doubt that this will happen. And in the end, due to the potential long trade loops messing things, you cannot predict if going to Cancon will help you as a seller.
If I'm missing something please let me know!
And so you know I'm going to Cancon, so sellers should be happy if I win their trade items. :cool:

So, for regular math-traders, in order to make this work out, should I be creating large random grab-bags of smaller games, or listing them separately?

[q="thepackrat"]So, for regular math-traders, in order to make this work out, should I be creating large random grab-bags of smaller games, or listing them separately?[/q]
It depends what you want to trade them for, and can you increase the value by increasing the number of games? My gut feeling is that much-wanted items trade for much-wanted items, and crap trades for crap. If you want crap, offer lots of crap items and you could get lucky. If you want something awesome, try to make an awesome combo. However note that two copies of Bootleggers is not better than one.

[q="thepackrat"]So, for regular math-traders, in order to make this work out, should I be creating large random grab-bags of smaller games, or listing them separately?[/q]
Also note, that if the main item is attractive enough, adding things to the bundle is unnecessary (because they want the game anyway) or might even put some people off (because some people might want the main item, but not go for it because they don't want to be lumbered with two smaller games which will never get played or traded and just take up cupboard space).
Bundles can be good to make your item stand out from identical items, or to put several smaller (but good) games together to increase your chances of being able to trade them for one bigger item.

[size=18][b]XMLAPI Math(s) Trade Tools[/b][/size]
I've made some updates to my maths trade tools, mainly involving the writing of a cache class to speed things up. There are three main utilities that you might find useful. All should be mobile friendly.
:d6-1: [url=http://zincgames.com/sandpit/bgg-geeklist.php?glid=75364][size=12] [b]Geeklist View[/b][/size][/url] offers a quick method of looking over the data in the maths trade geeklist. :d6-2: [url=http://zincgames.com/sandpit/bgg-gl-list.php?glid=75364][size=12] [b]GL List Only[/b][/size][/url] gives a list of all items on one page along with checkboxes to quickly highlight stuff you're interested in. At the request of Friendless: [q="Friendless"]Hey Ben, is it possible to hack your script so I can add a parameter to the URL, e.g. "?username=Friendless" so I can find only the items I've added to the trade?[/q] ...I've added in the ability to enter your username which will mark your items and attempt to create a blank trade list for you at the bottom of the window. Note that the maths trade codes rely on an educated guess that the diligent tiggers or someone like him will be kind enough to add the codes in with a bold tag in the comments 'cause that's all lazy old me is grepping ;) The next logical step will be to create a sortable list of the stuff you highlight and use that to generate set of trade codes. Speaking of wants: :d6-3: [url=http://zincgames.com/sandpit/bgg-group_games.php][size=12] [b]Group Games[/b][/size][/url] is linked from the bottom of the Geeklist View page. It retrieves the data for all of the usernames entered in the textarea at the top, then iterates through them to generate a list of group 'wants'. Of course, this only works if users have marked a game as wanted in their collection. This tool is also useful to see what games are owned by an arbitrary list of people so you can find that game you want to play before a Con. This one is the most likely to time out while it's building.
Please let me know if you spot any bugs (there will be some as it's all pretty hacky). The cache stuff is new, so that's probably going to be the biggest offender. Use these tools at your own peril! Be sure to check the original Geeklist for the correct codes before creating your maths trade lists.
Hey, Bærn Rokbottom, it's only finding 4 of my entries on the list, when I have many more than that.

[size=12][u]How to import the Trade List into Excel[/u][/size]
For those who use Excel to manage the trade list and/or assemble your Want List, this is an updated and revised version of my post from last year that apparently some people found helpful. The method is similar for all versions of Excel from 2003 on...
[b]1[/b]: Create a new (empty) worksheet. [b]2[/b]: On the [b]Data[/b] menu, go to [b]Import External Data[/b], and then click [b]Import Data[/b]. In Excel 2007/2010, click on [b]From Web[/b] on the Data ribbon. [b]3[/b]: Enter the data source as: [u]http://boardgamegeek.com/xmlapi2/geeklist/75364?type=thing&comments=1[/u]. This will create the query; click Import to bring it into your worksheet. [i]Note: For usability (see below) you might want to import starting at cell E1.[/i] [b]4[/b]: Some fields (columns) relate to the list itself, and can be deleted. The fields I recommend you retain are: [b]id6[/b], [b]objectid[/b], [b]objectname[/b], [b]username7[/b], [b]imageid[/b], [b]body[/b], [b]comment11[/b] and [b]username12[/b]. Turning OFF 'Wrap Text' on the table will reduce the display of the list to a manageable level. [b]5[/b]: The first rows will be the comments attached to the Geeklist, and can be deleted. This will leave you with just the trade list data, with some items (rows) duplicated where there are comments - you can filter them in a minute.
For usability I personally find it helpful to insert some identifiers... I use columns 'A', 'B', 'C' and 'D' as follows ([i]assuming you have set the table up as above, so your data is in remaining columns E-L[/i]): [b]6[/b]: In cell B2 enter the formula [b]=IF(E2=E1,B1,B1+1)[/b]; this gives you the trade list item number for each row (there will be some duplicates, for commented items). [b]7[/b]: In cell C2, enter the formula [b]=IF(AND(L2="tiggers",ISNUMBER(VALUE(MID(K2,4,3)))),MID(K2,4,9),IF(B2=B1,"","Item "&B2))[/b]; this looks for a trade code created by Tiggers, gives it a nominal identifier if not found, and a blank identifier for a duplicated (commented) line item. You can filter on this column to hide multiple lines of the same item. [b]8[/b]: In cell D2, enter the formula [b]="http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/75364/item/"&E2&"#item"&E2[/b]; this will give you a hyperlink reference to the item listing (right-click and select Hyperlink to turn it into an actual clickable link). [b]9[/b]: Copy the B2-D2 cell range down your table, and there are now some useful references. [b]10[/b]: I use Column A to put an "A", "B" or "C" priority on selected items to prompt me how badly I want to win them... add a filter to that column to drop out "blanks" and there's the basis for the Want List! [b]11[/b]: To update your list click within the table, go to the Table Tools menu and select 'Refresh'. [b]12[/b]: Filter on the [b]username7[/b] column (H) to find your own items, or on the [b]username12[/b] column (L) to revisit any smart-alec rejoinders that might still appeal.
I hope some of you find that useful.

Another helpful tip in finding potential trade matches is to find out who is interested in your games, and find out what they have for trade.
1. Some people give a thumbs up to the games they're interested in. 2. Click the number to the left of the thumb on your trade item. It will bring up a list of people who thumbed your item, as illustrated below:
[ImageID=1196887]
3. Open each name in a new tab (or window, or do it one at a time) to get to the user profile. 4. Within each person's profile, click 'Contributions', then scroll down and click on their 'Geeklist Items' (you can see where I've done this for Neil Thomson in the image below. The 'Geeklist Items' link is in the very bottom right of the image).
[ImageID=1196891 medium]
5. This will bring up a list of all the items they've added to geeklists, scroll through this and you'll see some of the items they've added to the Math Trade. 6. This may help you to get an idea of what the people interested in your game have up for trade. This helps 'narrow down' trade matches and find closer matches for your trades.
Of course, not everyone thumbs the items they're interested in, people may change their minds, and they may not be interested in a direct trade for your item, but it may help in some small way.

That's my main gripe.

I don't like it either. The algorithm used in the math(s) trade aims to make the biggest number of trades possible. If people short circuit the process by making pre-emptive trades, the swaps made in those instances will use the shortest possible paths - ie. two participants (not to mention that 'swapping' for cash is not really even a swap). The same items, if swapped via the the algorithm could potentially satisfy a lot more participants.
Why can't people just wait and do things as they're supposed to be done? It's like kids picking the Smarties off the top of a birthday cake.

[q="snog"]
Why can't people just wait and do things as they're supposed to be done? It's like kids picking the Smarties off the top of a birthday cake.
[/q]
I agree with your sentiment here, but I agree more with David Cox's - we're here to trade. If we're discovering that someone else wants what we have and has what we want, it seems better to make those two people happy than maybe make them and someone else happy, or maybe not make them happy at all, or maybe just make someone else happy (not that making other people happy is a bad thing...).
I'm going in circles here, but the bottom line is that it's a big trade and there's enough stuff here that we can probably still all be happy after the trade, no matter what disappears early!

[q="snog"]Why can't people just wait and do things as they're supposed to be done? It's like kids picking the Smarties off the top of a birthday cake.[/q]
In my opinion the main contributor to this "problem" is simply poor housekeeping. Many of the items submitted to the maths trade were not flagged as "For Trade" in people's collections. Most of the items added with "Buy it Now" values are not listed in the Marketplace.
BGG has an excellent tool for finding potential trades, including the ability to restrict matches to Australians only. But, as Friendless noted above, for it to work everyone's trade lists need to be up to date. Similarly, BGG has a perfectly viable Marketplace for those who so strongly advocate that "receiver pays" should be the preferred method of moving games around the country.
I understand the frustration in seeing desirable items disappear off the trade list but, as David points out, from the owner's perspective all they want is their game traded (or sold). However, like any system, it's only going to be good as what people put into it.
Pat, if you'll please forgive me for singling you out as an example to demonstrate my point: you have 7 items as "Want in Trade", but nothing "For Trade". Looking at the first item on your list ([thing=8481][/thing]) there are two other active Aussie users offering it in trade... but what do you expect them to do? Wait until it gets added to a maths trade and see what you can offer? Fair enough, but there are 189 users "wanting" this game, so it shouldn't be unexpected that there are 188 other opportunities for someone else to jump in and try and snaffle it as soon as they see it available.
To single myself out now: I added 23 items to the maths trade, all of which I have had listed as "for trade" for some time... yet I have since received over a dozen private trade offers, some within minutes of having added the games to the list! But, at the end of the day, if it's a desirable trade for me then I am going to take it because that's why it got added in the first place.

[q="ausminstrel"]But, at the end of the day, if it's a desirable trade for me then I am going to take it because that's why it got added in the first place.[/q]
The other thing to keep in mind is that if you put your trade list in there is no guarantee that your items will trade, even if some people want them.
The software goes for the biggest trades possible. If someone makes you a firm offer beforehand you take your fate in your own hands by accepting it, rather than waiting and hoping that your trades will be the ones used by the software to maximise the trade loop.

You all make valid points - blast you!
I shall endeavour to calm down.

[q=paraphrasing the collective]We're here to trade so what's wrong with trading?[/q]
When individuals only looks after their own short term interests, society suffers as a whole. More prior back-door trades mean less trades in the final results. Your short term gain is screwing somebody else over somewhere later (but you'll never know who, so what do you care). The pre-trade games are popular ones and would definitely have traded in the MT (and you could have put a very short want list for them too), so why can't you just wait, huh?
On a separate point, does nobody find it ironic that a whole bunch of board gamer are [u]unable to play by the rules[/u]?
It think this is what bugs me the most about this whole situation.

[q="snog"]You all make valid points - blast you!
I shall endeavour to calm down.[/q] If you can't rage out on the internet, where can you? I think your point was well-made too: the early trades feel like something that is, while not technically "against the rules", sort of unfair -- like someone who slips a bouncer or maître d' $50 instead of waiting in line. You probably stay in the queue and think, "why didn't I think of that?" But you probably still say in the queue.
I personally find it frustrating because I do not have the sort of personality that makes hustling like this easy -- cold contacting people I don't know well or at all to "make a deal", or whatever. (I suck at negotiation games too!) The idea of an algorithm smoothing the way and providing an even playing field is appealing. The idea that other players can cheat isn't, and the fact that the "rules" against it are arbitrary and obviously self-imposed doesn't make it less frustrating.
The logic of it is fine, but on an emotional level it isn't, so you can pry my right to complain about it from my cold, dead hands. :P

This makes no sense to me - there are several rules.
the game that I sold was advertised in the marketplace several weeks prior to the Math Trade and was purchased by a non-participant. Should I say to him, "I'll sell it to you in a month's time if I don't trade it"?
The game I purchased out of the Math Trade was currently listed in the MP and the seller told me he had a couple of enquiries from overseas regarding purchase.
Rules??? The rules of the marketplace or the rules of the math trade. Commonsense should always override rules.

[q="da pyrate"] This makes no sense to me - there are several rules.
the game that I sold was advertised in the marketplace several weeks prior to the Math Trade and was purchased by a non-participant. Should I say to him, "I'll sell it to you in a month's time if I don't trade it"? [/q]

Personally, I've both made and received some early trade offers. In the case of the ones I made, all the games were already available in multiple copies in the list, and were poor matches size-wise for what I was trading. I also warned someone who was eyeing something in my for trade/marketplace lists to let him know it would go into the trade if he didn't grab it. [q="srand"]I personally find it frustrating because I do not have the sort of personality that makes hustling like this easy -- cold contacting people I don't know well or at all to "make a deal", or whatever.[/q]
I am sorry (and truly surprised) to hear that Sam. I am not sure that "hustling" is the right word, that's certainly not the same thing as cold contacting. But part of being here in what is essentially a social network is reaching out to other people about common interests. I would encourage you to make contact with me any time about any thing here that takes your interest, including trade offers or queries... as long as you are not offended if the answer is no. (It's okay if you feel a sense of crushing defeat, but just don't be offended!)
And I am confident I speak for most other contributors here, many of whom I have traded with from here on the other side of the country, and not one of whom I have had a bad experience with. If you operate in good faith and honestly, respect the viewpoint of others, and understand that most of us encourage negotiation as part of the trade process (and accordingly may value items very differently to you) so that the worst that can happen is that it ends with a "no, thank you" but no bad feelings, then step up and see what you can get. :)

[q="some_guy"]On a separate point, does nobody find it ironic that a whole bunch of board gamer are [u]unable to play by the rules[/u]?[/q]
I see... you're one of those gamers who plays by the spirit of the rules, as opposed to those of us who play by the letter of the rules. We should have a game some time :devil: .
But really, I didn't have any perception there was such a rule, not even implied. I see the maths trade as being an additional mechanism on top of normal BGG trading, to find another set of trade opportunities.

So the codes are all done. If you find an error or discrepancy please let me or Rene know and we'll correct it. We've tried to consistenly use the same codes as much as possible for entries of the same game but they may not always match up so be sure to double check what you're selecting.
I'm going to limit the number of edits as much as possible so that folks can begin work or their want lists, but remember the deadline for the official items list is 6pm Wednesday so there [i]could [/i]be changes up until then.

Thanks guys, let us know of any issues with the codes.
As per tiggers comment
[q=tiggers]remember the deadline for the official items list is 6pm Wednesday so there could be changes up until then[/q]
there could be changes to the codes.

[q="freelunch"]this is the second Maths Trade I've found out about the day after submissions closed :(
where's the best place to subscribe to to make sure I'm in the loop for the next one?[/q]
But there's only one game on your For Trade list. :devil:
I agree with Friendless & ausminstrel that things would be easier if we all kept our trade lists up to date on BGG, especially when there's only so many of us in Australia compared to other continents. Trade opportunity don't seem to be that easy to come by.
The only other bit of advice I could give is that you can still participate in the trade by offering cash (only) in your want list for any games here that you're interested in buying. Let us know if you need help setting up a wishlist to do this.
Ben :)

[q="mr_lunch"] 2 lots of Blood Bowl: Living RuleBook %ORCBB: 305-ORCBB 306-DKELF [/q]
Correct me if I'm wrong but aren't these two items different?
:shake: my head at the number of different codes for the same games.

Because David listed the two sets of minis under the parent rulebook, the XMLAPI gives the same item ID.
I think your codes are nicely descriptive of the games, but I'm sure it's tedious to do. If we were to automate it, what would be the best approach? I was thinking something along the lines of:
:nostar: 4 digit item number, padded with zeroes and followed by a dash :nostar: Strip any punctuation from the game name :nostar: Grab the first letter of each word :nostar: Trim that to 5 characters :nostar: Pad right with 'X', if required
eg 0305-BBLRX

[q="mr_lunch"]Because David listed the two sets of minis under the parent rulebook, the XMLAPI gives the same item ID.
I think your codes are nicely descriptive of the games, but I'm sure it's tedious to do. If we were to automate it, what would be the best approach? I was thinking something along the lines of:
:nostar: 4 digit item number, padded with zeroes and followed by a dash :nostar: Strip any punctuation from the game name :nostar: Grab the first letter of each word :nostar: Trim that to 5 characters :nostar: Pad right with 'X', if required
eg 0305-BBLRX[/q]
Yeah finding a balence between being descriptive in a useful way and someone(s) not having to enter 1000+ codes will be tricky.
The problem may be with items that have numbers in the names - especially wargames. Now you could programme around these, but it would be easier just to leave wargames out entirely.
[size=8](Ducks!)[/size]

[q="mr_lunch"][size=18][b]XMLAPI Math(s) Trade Tools[/b][/size] :d6-2: [url=http://zincgames.com/sandpit/bgg-gl-list.php?glid=75364][size=12] [b]GL List Only[/b][/size][/url] gives a list of all items on one page along with checkboxes to quickly highlight stuff you're interested in.[/q]
New version online now:
:star: Should fix the +1000 item codes. :star: If you insert your username, it will also get your want list from BGG and highlight [-]the stuff that you really wanted that has already been traded away[/-] those items. :star: Makes a guess at the duplicate protection codes.
This tool is to help you block in your trade lists. Do not trust it -- check everything yourself before submitting a list.

[q="tiggers"] Now you could programme around these, but it would be easier just to leave wargames out entirely.
[size=8](Ducks!)[/size]
[/q]
Why you ...

[q="mr_lunch"]If we were to automate it, what would be the best approach?[/q]
We could use just the number. Easy peasy lemon squeezy. With your want-list generator there's less chance of error. I should set up a page on my site where want lists can be submitted across the web, so I don't need to search my geekmail. If only I could do that before Wednesday when I'm due to be inundated.

It's a real shame the want-lists aren't public so people could react to them :)
B>

[q="thepackrat"]It's a real shame the want-lists aren't public so people could react to them :)
B>[/q]
As they come in, there is often an update of as-yet unwanted items so folks can make changes to make the loops bigger.

You know BGG already has some very good software that already does what alot of people are asking for.
It's called the Online Want List Generator (OLWLG) http://boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/OLWLG
Lots of American and european Math Trades use it. I've used it, it great! Check it out before anyone goes and re-invents the wheel.

We used JeffyJeff's OLWLG for one of the first trades. Since then the time it takes him to maintain it has meant that he will only add trades that he can take part in. Our lists always start with [q]This trade is open to Australian BGGers only.[/q]

[q="mr_lunch"]We used JeffyJeff's OLWLG for one of the first trades. Since then the time it takes him to maintain it has meant that he will only add trades that he can take part in. Our lists always start with [q]This trade is open to Australian BGGers only.[/q][/q]
BGGer!

I'll pop an inventory of this up when I've had a chance to check it, but from memory it's missing a US Infantry piece, which is easy to substitute one of the invading pieces for until you take a US Infantry casualty (i.e. in turn one).
There is a rip in the board too, but this doesn't affect gameplay.
It's the edition with Saddam Hussein on the front, which I think is the first edition.
I'm planning to be at Cancon.
UPDATE: I've done an inventory.
The box is a little beat up, but not at all bad for a 25-year-old game.
The board rip isn't as bad as I thought it was. It's there and obvious, but it is cosmetic damage only, really.
It's missing one die (a d8) - again, this is a minor issue as it still has 3 d8s anyway.
There is indeed one US Infantry piece missing, but as mentioned above, this is easily solvable.
A couple of other infantry pieces are a little 'weak in the knees'...
There is also a bag of surplus pieces for the invaders, so you have replacements if you lose something.

For anyone who is interested in pre-trades, I'll be in Adelaide next week and Melbourne the week of Christmas.

item.comment: That's like calling Gettysburg the Pea Ridge of the east....;)

[q="da pyrate"]That's like calling Gettysburg the Pea Ridge of the east....;)[/q]
I've always wondered why there weren't more games on the Pea Ridge of the East.

[q="petegs"][q="da pyrate"]That's like calling Gettysburg the Pea Ridge of the east....;)[/q]
I've always wondered why there weren't more games on the Pea Ridge of the East.[/q]
I can't even see the similarity - Pea Ridge was 17,000 confederates attacking 10,000 federals in a double envelopment and the rebels were defeated. In scale it was tiny when compared to Gettysburg.

[q="da pyrate"][q="petegs"][q="da pyrate"]That's like calling Gettysburg the Pea Ridge of the east....;)[/q]
I've always wondered why there weren't more games on the Pea Ridge of the East.[/q]
I can't even see the similarity - Pea Ridge was 17,000 confederates attacking 10,000 federals in a double envelopment and the rebels were defeated. In scale it was tiny when compared to Gettysburg.
[/q]
The only similarity I can see, and this is really [i]stretching[/i] the word, is that the battle took place at a crossroads.

Burg is German for Ridge and you Pea in the Getty. Makes sense to me... :what:
Perhaps because it was a decisive battle where the "War" was turned?
Dunno.

item.comment: wow - didn't expect to see this here quite so quickly given the general feedback on the geek. What is impetus for adding this one Jason? Didn't meet expectations / not enough people to play it with / other?

I really like SE4X. It plays reasonably quickly and is very aggressive and brutal. The only slight niggle I have is that the tech upgrades can be quite fiddly to keep track of for each individual group of ships, but there is a variant in the rules that allows for instant tech upgrades anyway.
I just can't see SE4X getting played a great deal. The beauty of a large trade like this is you can gauge interest and be picky in what you'll swap for. I haven't seen a great deal of 'instant trade' or 'exciting' options listed so far, but I'll wait and see what appears once January has rolled around.
Let's just say that I'll be handing in a short trade list with this one.
I'll give you a copy of [i]Roma[/i] for it.
Maybe you could add in a copy of "In the Shadow of the Emperor" as a sweetener. :)

item.comment: Did you play it with just 2 players? I reckon this game is a fantastic 2-player game but a very ordinary game with 3 or 4 players.

[q="snog"]Did you play it with just 2 players? I reckon this game is a fantastic 2-player game but a very ordinary game with 3 or 4 players.[/q]
Yeah I picked this up for its 2-player play. I just need to get to it.

[q="snog"]Did you play it with just 2 players? I reckon this game is a fantastic 2-player game but a very ordinary game with 3 or 4 players.[/q]
I'd disagree, I think it does very well indeed with 3 players.
B>

[q="snog"]Did you play it with just 2 players? I reckon this game is a fantastic 2-player game but a very ordinary game with 3 or 4 players.[/q]
Both games were 2p. I've been meaning to try it again, but 3+ years on the back-burner is just too long...
Yeah, I know that feelin' all too well.
IMHO the main problem of more than two players is the dilemma that arises from the politices of who prevents a connection victory.

[q="fFish"]IMHO the main problem of more than two players is the dilemma that arises from the politices of who prevents a connection victory.[/q]
People who don't want to lose. I think most people will work it out after they've spent a few minutes bickering while the third player romps home. After that, we tended to find that folks generally moved to avoid connection victories near themselves as a matter of course while building, so it became more of a threat.
B>

item.comment: I don't think the math trade algorithm allows for you to choose where it goes.
[q="tiggers"]I don't think the math trade algorithm allows for you to choose where it goes.[/q] I think Patrick is just asking nicely that no-one outside those categories puts it on their want list.
It doesn't fit in a flat rate box?

[q="PBrennan"][q="srand"]I think Patrick is just asking nicely that no-one outside those categories puts it on their want list.[/q]
Exactly. I'll pay postage as per the rules. If I get stung, so be it. If someone outside the area wants it and is prepared to share postage, also happy. But I'm asking the gaming community to play nice. I like the idea of area limitations for big box games (it doesn't fit in an eligible flat rate box) as it gets these big box games into the maths trade when they otherwise wouldn't be included. It requires trust. I'm willing to give it.
If people want to debate the merits or allowability, let's move the discussion to the thread provided in the header for detailed discussions rather than clog up the list with comments. Thanks.[/q]
Fair enough. I just wanted to it to be clear.

item.body:
[b]From the game page:[/b]
Phil T. Rich, millionaire has been stolen by an unsuspected criminal and it's your job to figure out who is the culprit. In this ten chapter investigation find out who has kidnapped Phil or potentially killed him. Use you skills with the Crime Computer and other gadgets as underwater goggles and x-ray vision. And on your way complete puzzling challenges and mini-games. As you investigate through 12 suspect you'll get closer to solving the mystery of Phil T. Rich.
This game is essentially a "Where's Wally" type game, where players search for objects hidden in the pictures, with some mini-games and a storyline thrown in for good measure. It's entertaining enough while you're waiting for a take-away order, or to see a doctor, but it's a bit hard on the eyes to spot many of the hidden objects.
I've played it through to the end - now it's someone else's turn :)
[size=16][b]Edit - this is a game for the Nintendo DS[/b][/size]

[size=18][b]Nintendo DS Game[/b][/size]
Nintendo Flips (interactive books) [b] Artemis Fowl by Eoin Colfer.[/b] Includes: Artemis Fowl ; The Arctic Incident ; The Eternity Code ; The Opal Deception ; The Lost Colony ; The Time Paradox.
Interactive features: Collect codes as you read through the adventures to translate bonus Gnomish text! Touch links within the book to find additional facts and information on story content! Share a chapter with a friend by sending it via DS Wireless Communications!
This "game" is "lightly used". It was driving me batty to read on the small Nintendo screens, and I have a Kindle now. :D

[size=18][b]Nintendo DS "Game"[/b][/size]
[b]100 Classic Book Collection[/b]
Enjoy reading 100 classic books from some of the greatest authors ever, including Shakespeare, Dickens, Austen and many more. Browse a virtual bookshelf. There's something for everyone! Get custom recommendations from the Book Guide. Read book introductions and author information.
Opened but unused. I have a Kindle now, so this is no longer required. :D

As a bonus, I will include a set of Mort Kunstler ACW cards - a full set of 90 cards - these are not a game - they have value purely as art and as military memorabilia.

[-]"Granada is the re-implementation of Alhambra that improves on all fronts. The board and tiles are larger and brighter, but for more strategic play, every tile can be flipped to deploy an alternate color--effectively doubling the size of the market. The most significant improvement is the scoring, which dynamically values each color based on its total popularity at the table. A gamer's Alhambra." - Trip Godel (tgodel) [/-] [-]All games are complete & in good condition.[/-]

item.objectname: Spicks and Specks: The Board Game
item.body:
The shows over ... or is it? Here's your chance to play it again. Your chance to be Alan or Myf.
Plus
[ImageID=370330][thing=28857][/thing]
"This is an abstract tile placement game onto a square board. Scoring is different, but game play is similar to Ta Yu - take turns playing oblong Ta Yu like pieces with different paths on them. Aim to cordon off corners of the board (inside which you capture opponent's pieces and can place your own at end-game) with the aim of maximising the number of path connections onto the board. Clever, and probably pretty deep (only played once), with the smallish game board keeping games to a neat length but, like all 2 player abstracts, it depends on your AP." - Patrick Brennan (PBrennan)
Both games are still in shrink.
Plus
[ImageID=550588][thing=42898][/thing]

This one is, if not light, nicely abstract and easy to explain to a range of game players. Java is brutally thinky and prone to long pauses (and no less cool for it).

item.comment: After recent plays of Navegador I'm hot for the rondel games. I'd like to try this out.

If this is one you're getting rid of for lack of opportunities, we were talking about it at the Pancake Parlour last night after Navegador so I'm quite sure there are plenty of locals who'd be happy to give it a go...
It's OK Sam I have the original as well. I had to toss up which one had to go and 2030 lost. :cry: And I will actually bring it (original) to Pancakes next time.
I saw the guys playing that the other evening, I assumed it was some sort of Risk variant. :blush:

[q="Friendless"]I saw the guys playing that the other evening, I assumed it was some sort of Risk variant. :blush:[/q]
Not at all! I've had the chance to play a couple of times now and it's very cool. I like how control of the different armies is constantly in flux and you're just always trying to position yourself to make the most profit.
Hmmm....enjoying profiting from the misery of others....does that make me a bad person?

item.comment: And with this item a new Aussie math trade record is set for items listed. lets hope we can set one for traded items too.

[q="thepackrat"]What's the previous traded record?[/q]
I've checked and the records for items, trades and the percentage traded are all from the same math trade: http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/61984/australian-maths-trade-christmas-2010-now-with-cas
664 items, 446 traded (67.1%)
For all previous Aussie math trades the numbers look like this (for anyone who cares):
Trade/ items listed/ traded/ percentage:
1 576 283 49.1% 2 362 195 53.8% 3 506 212 44.5% 4 245 64 26% 5 503 274 54.5% 6 417 206 49.4% 7 664 446 67.1% 8 442 227 51%
Average items: 464 Average traded: 238 Average percentage traded: 51.3%
Man, if I can move half of this cra... uh, top shelf merchandise, I'll be thrilled! :)
So this should be Aus trade number 9? I'll correct the header...
What's the biggest bgg math trade ever?

# Box
* 1 box
# Terrain & Ships
* 18 Terrain Pieces * [-]6 Blue Ships[/-] * [-]6 Blue Ships[/-]
# Literature
* 1 Rulebook * [-]1 How to paint Man O'War (missing sails)[/-]
# Accessories
* 1 Empire Fleet List * 1 Pirate Fleet List * 1 Chart Sheet * 1 Compass with Arrow counter * 1 Direction Indicator * 1 Elf Range Ruler * 2 Range Rulers
# Cards
* 2 Wizard Cards * 32 Man O' War Cards * 32 Magic Cards
# Templates
* 2 Turning Templates * 6 Red Empire Ship Templates * 6 Green Pirate Ship Templates
# Counters
* 2 Admiral Counters * 2 Whirlpool Counters * 4 Large Abandoned Counters * 6 Small Abandoned Counters * 6 Treasure Counters * 6 War Dancer Counters * 8 Sinking Ship Counters (4 each of 2 types) * 8 Submerged Counters * 8 Wizard Counters * 8 Elite Counters * 8 Sailor Counters * 8 Seadog Counters * 8 Cut Throat Counters * 8 Veteran Counters * 12 Flagship Counters * 12 Captures Counters * 12 Sunk Counters * 16 Wizard Colour Counters * 16 Wound Counters * 18 No-Firing Counters * 18 No-Movement Counters * 40 Blaze Counters * 75 Damage Counters * [-]75[/-] 74 Crew Counters

item.objectname: The Pillars of the Earth: Expansion Set
item.body:
[b]Pictured [/b]edition, in shrink. We already have the base game and this expansion.
I will [b]not [/b]be at CanCon, but [i]may [/i]be able to arrange delivery to CanCon if required.
Note this is an [b]expansion [/b]to the original game, you will need [i]Pillars of the Earth[/i] to play it.
This expansion "expands the game a couple of ways: raising the number of players to 6, and adding to the gameplay with new locations, craftsmen, and resources."
item.comment:
The expansion increases the maximum number of players (2-4 becomes 2-6). It also fixes the random action order, which improves the game significantly. Strongly recommended if you have the base game.
Also note: the expansion fits in the original box.
Is it weird that I want to trade for this but I also have Pillars on the Math Trade? I could see this ending in disaster for me.

[q="Tyndal"]Is it weird that I want to trade for this but I also have Pillars on the Math Trade? I could see this ending in disaster for me.[/q]
Au contraire - think, rather, that it could end with you having your first new entry for the next math trade!

Original boxed game. All the cardboard has been punched, and all the plastic minis have been removed from their sprues (which have been discarded) but the game is complete, with rulebooks and all the tokens, terrain pieces, and even the extra arms/weapons for all the miniatures. All the contents are in very good (played once) condition, with the following exceptions:
-Most of the cardboard terrain pieces have a stripe of tape along the edges where they attach to the plastic bulkheads - this was done to prevent fraying, and the tape is mostly concealed when the terrain is assembled, but it's probably a downer for collectors nonetheless.
-There is 15cm rip/tear in the front face of the box cover (flimsy GW cardboard is prone to this). This was present when I bought the last copy from a GW store all those many years ago, and is not an indication of mistreatment. The box remains sturdy.
-The models, though unpainted, do each have a number painted on the edge of the clip-on base in primer. I doubt this will be a problem for anyone.
I am also including:
-Four white-metal minis, consisting of one leader and one heavy for each of the two factions included in this base set (Orlock and Goliath) bringing the total number of minis up to 28.
-An "Imperial Bastion", sold by GW as a 40K prop, that is assembled from the same plastic bulkheads and cardboard as the other terrain, and makes a good extra terrain piece.

item.body:
This package contains the first three books in this series:
[thing=44146][/thing] [ImageID=533754]
[thing=44147][/thing] [ImageID=562828]
[thing=44149][/thing] [ImageID=562832]
[b]PLUS[/b] another (unrelated) book:
[i]The Art Of Texas Hold 'Em[/i] by the game designers James Ernest (Cheapass Games) and Mike Selinker
These are the original role-playing choose-your-own-adventure books by Steve Jackson and Ian Livingstone, the founders of Games Workshop!
All three are in used book condition - and #2 has a chunk of pages that have come loose from the binding but are still holding together - but perfectly readable and playable.
The Art Of Texas Hold 'Em is in Excellent Condition, and will show you "how to go from Beginner to Winner".

[b]PLUS[/b] The First Two Expansions:
[thing=34499][/thing] [ImageID=376993] and [thing=40210][/thing] [ImageID=445501]
Excellent Condition.
However, the following (utterly non-essential) components are missing:
(1) The base game is missing the four German summary sheets/play aids (the English ones are there, though!) and the box insert (which was removed to make room for the expansions);
(2) Expansion #1, The Gathering Storm, is missing the 17 blank ("make your own") cards, the contest entry card (the contest is now over), and the box (as the components are now in the box for the base game);
(3) Expansion #2, Rebel vs. Imperium, is missing the contest entry card (the contest is now over) and the box (as the components are now in the box for the base game).
Again, note that NONE of these missing items affect play of the game (unless you're playing with Germans and they need the play aids in their language).
The base game and the two expansions are all great and this is one of my favourite games! But these are extra copies that I do not need.
I will accept either a trade or cash ($65, which also covers my shipping costs).

item.body:
Good Condition. It's actually in Fine to Excellent Condition, except that it was missing one wooden cylinder (which I have replaced with a perfectly functioning substitute) and the sand timer. I've replaced the timer with a mechanical one from Scattergories. While it's pretty much the right length (3 minutes), it's not optimum for the game because you can't easily replicate the time one team used so the second team has the same amount. It would be best to use one of the digital timers now available for phones, iPads, etc.
This is a party/dexterity game where one team member is blindfolded and the others are giving verbal instructions about how to build a structure from differently-shaped blocks. Hilarity ensues.
I will accept games or cash. As I am entering this close to the deadline for entries, I have not been able to determine what my cash asking price will be. However, as this list will soon be closed for changes, I will be publishing that information on my blog at http://thesecretbreadempire.blogspot.com/2012/01/my-cure-cancer-game-sale-with-other.html - [i]just add $15 to the listed price to cover possible shipping anywhere in Australia and that would be the amount I'm asking for the math trade.[/i]
[b]NOTE: If you would like to buy this game, you should contact me directly before trade lists need to be submitted. You'll probably get it for cheaper (because shipping costs to you will be exact, and could even be FREE at Cancon) and you might get some other stuff for free!
